description.plain:
The Australian singer-songwriter, whose real name is James Keogh, described the inspiration for his stage name:

I got my name from a book called Bliss by Peter Carey, which is an Australian story. I had about five or six songs I was really stoked with, and I just wanted to have a name to put with that new collection of songs that wasn’t my name, because people always mispronounce Keough because it’s got the ‘gh’ at the end. So I used Vance Joy, which is a character [in the book] — he’s like a storyteller, so it’s a cool name.

body.plain:
The Australian singer-songwriter, whose real name is James Keogh, described the inspiration for his stage name:

I got my name from a book called Bliss by Peter Carey, which is an Australian story. I had about five or six songs I was really stoked with, and I just wanted to have a name to put with that new collection of songs that wasn’t my name, because people always mispronounce Keough because it’s got the ‘gh’ at the end. So I used Vance Joy, which is a character [in the book] — he’s like a storyteller, so it’s a cool name.

songs.title: Riptide

description.plain:
The intro and first single to Vance Joy’s debut EP God Loves You When You’re Dancing was a critical and commercial success. Critics praised its clever lyrics filled with pop culture references. It peaked at 30 on the Billboard Hot 100 charts.

It is a weird mish-mash of ideas. Sometimes, you know, I will try to write and stick a bunch of different ideas and images together and it won’t work and I’ll think, “oh, that doesn’t sound right” or “it sounds too weird and it all conflicts with each other,” but for some reason that all came together well for “Riptide,” and when things happen like that it is a bit beyond your control. I had a bunch of different ideas and words, it wasn’t even a general story line like I was referring to an experience or anything. It is more like a stream of consciousness. – Vance Joy

According to an interview with American Songwriter, the song remained untouched and unfinished for four years from when Vance started writing it in 2008 until 2012. During long afternoons while his roommate was at work, he would work on it bit by bit. One day after a brief trip to the store, he returned home and played the melody on the ukulele, which he built on to finish the song a few days later.

On June 11, 2020, the RIAA certified ‘Riptide’ as 6x platinum, Vance Joy’s highest certification to date.

songs.embed_content: Read “Riptide” by Vance Joy on Genius

songs.title: Georgia

description.plain:
“Georgia” is the sixth single off Vance Joy’s critically acclaimed album, Dream Your Life Away.  Released in February of 2015 and charting high on the Australian ARIA Chart, the song proved to show Joy’s debut album was gaining traction.

With its understated folk-style guitar picking working as the backbone, the vocal melodies carry this homage to love and all its complexities and seeming contradictions to great heights.  Joy gives a subtle nod to Ray Charles' 1960 hit, “Georgia On My Mind,” which later became the official song of the State.

songs.full_title: Mess Is Mine by Vance Joy
songs.title: Mess Is Mine

description.plain:
“Mess is Mine” is the second single from Vance Joy’s 2014 album Dream Your Life Away.

In an interview with Lewis ‘Homebrew’ McKirdy, Vance gave some insight into these lyrics:

When you’re in love with someone, you take on the whole package. It’s messy, but the mess of life is the good thing. The special thing about relationships is taking on the good and the bad and the messy aspects.
